data.text:
Gimp 2.10.32 review, Gimp software reviews. If you want to know a review about the last version of Gimp, a photoshop alternative, Keep reading.

GIMP 2.10.32 was published today as a fresh maintenance update to the GIMP 2.10 stable series, while the GIMP development team is still hard at work on the next major upgrade, GIMP 3.0.

GIMP 2.10.32 arrives almost six months after GIMP 2.10.30 with a slew of new features, including support for importing 8-bit and 16-bit CMYK(A) TIFF files, importing and exporting BigTIFF files, and built-in support for JPEG XL files (without the need of a third-party plugin).

This release also improves support for importing XCF files by ensuring that more data is recovered from corrupted XCF files. It includes a new “There’s a new “Flip the picture vertically on export” option that lets you flip DDS images during export, as well as a new “Visible layers” option that lets you export the whole image render.

GIMP 2.10.32 also includes several information handling enhancements, particularly for PSD (Photoshop) files, a new IPTC option when exporting WebP pictures, and the ability to import translucent EPS files.

The BMP, RAW, and DICOM file formats have also been enhanced, and the Text tool now supports translated glyphs. Furthermore, all official themes now have an on-hover indication around the eye and link toggles in Layer/Channel/Path Dialog tree-views.

Finally, GIMP’s Dark theme now has a new on-hover effect for the radio menu items to enhance readability. The Color icon theme now has thin contrast borders around the ‘close’ and ‘detach’ icons to increase readability.

THE ULTIMATE KRITA REVIEW

GIMP 2.10 Review: User Interface

GIMP 2.10.32’s user interface is simple and straightforward. File, Edit, View, and History are the four primary components of the UI. The Tools menu, which comprises the most frequently used tools, may be found under the File section. The Edit area provides picture-altering tools such as the Paint, Pen, and Clone tools. The View section includes an image preview as well as tools for cropping and resizing photographs. The History section keeps track of the modifications you make to photos. Overall, the user interface is well-designed and simple to navigate.

GIMP review: Image Editing Tools

GIMP’s current version has a plethora of image-altering features. From simple picture cropping and scaling to more sophisticated and intricate features, it’s everything here. Let’s go through some highlights.

Support for high bit depth: GIMP was recently updated to provide image processing with 32-bit precision per color channel. This means you may deal with high-quality files such as TIFFs in their original integrity.

Photo editing tools: GIMP shines when it comes to touching up and modifying photos. It provides a comprehensive set of tools for rectifying faults committed during the capture process. Rotate and Crop may be used to smooth out a horizon line, Brightness and Contrast can be used to bring up an underexposure, and Lens Distortion can be used to compensate for optical imperfections in your lens.

Brushes: While GIMP isn’t as strong as programs like Krita, it does have a full set of brushes that are also customizable and downloadable. If you’re looking for a certain brush that isn’t in the default collection, there’s a strong possibility you can brew it yourself or discover someone who has. This brings us to

Plugins: As previously said, GIMP is entirely open source, but you don’t need to be a coding genius to use it. There are several helpful plugins available for download that will add functionality to your version of GIMP that is not included with the installation.

File compatibility: GIMP can open almost every sort of picture you’re likely to come across. Along with PNG and JPEG images, it can also handle PSD, PDF, BMP, SVG, and TIFF files, as well as a slew of others.

GIMP review: what’s missing?

GIMP is so feature-rich and customizable that we could spend thousands of words detailing all of its capabilities and what you can do with it — but then we’d be here all day. So, it may be better to list the things that GIMP noticeably lacks or performs poorly, especially when compared to competitors such as Photoshop.

GIMP isn’t a good text editor, and it’s not the ideal application for dealing with text and images. Adding effects to text may be a lengthy and involved process, and it’s amazing how many steps are required just to make text appear decent. If you’re seeking for free software to design posters or flyers, Canva is definitely the finest option.

There is no smartphone/tablet support: GIMP is a desktop-only application. If you’re used to utilizing Photoshop’s mobile or tablet versions to edit up photographs on the move, you’ll lose that feature if you convert to GIMP.

Should I download GIMP?
